Message.Msg: read up on mathematical induction and probability theory. It could be tough for habitual gamblers to tolerate the discipline, but well worth the try. Discipline, discipline is key. Biased induction is about all I see on this thread from top to bottom.
He must have gotten an attitude adjustment.

Message.Title: US Generation X and the destruction of GOP
Message.Msg: The GOP simply has no future, and of course the GOP is the main defender of the oil industry, and irrational policies of many stripes besides. Its base of support is coming from World War II era voters and “boomers,” people who grew up in the era of American media censorship, sexism, and religion – indeed Hollywood’s the Hays Code, which defines their ethos, was inspired by a Jesuit Priest. Generation X’s values are entirely different and they will never think nor vote as the older American generations. *materialistic values, greed for wealth personal fame and accomplishment, and non-community mindedness and elitism defines “X.” This will rule out social conservatism and leftist liberalism. *X is far better educated than the older generations too, with rates of college graduation a couple times higher, and education and rationalism correlates negatively with votes for groups like the GOP, and libertarian values as well. *Purity is an element of an elitist X type mentality as well, and an aspiration for purity extended to one’s surroundings is conducive to pro-environmentalist thought. ……… It’s unlikely the immigrants will be able to out vote X either – it is nearly 80 million strong in the USA. That is more than enough for it to dictate its views once the World War II liberals and GOP voters who are making the USA impossible to govern expire. Just look to Germany for a clue to what America’s future looks like. The sort of right-wing we have here is a good match for the X type values. We are in charge now because the World War II generation in Germany is unlike the American world war II generation, and their votes + X ensures an X victory. The question is how much damage can the hippies and boomer and other cause before they lose power…

Message.Title: Carol Browner, Obama's former Climate Czar, shared her insights on how climate legislation failed in Congress in 2010, what to expect from
Message.Msg: Carol Browner, Obama's former Climate Czar, shared her insights on how climate legislation failed in Congress in 2010, what to expect from Obama's second term, and why it's so hard to get people serious about climate change. by Ankit Jain - Apr 26, 2013 3:03 am CDT Former Climate Czar Carol Browner was handpicked by President Obama to serve as director of the White House Office of Energy and Climate Change Policy and served as the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for eight years, longer than anyone else who has held the position. She is now a Distinguished Senior Fellow at the Center for American Progress and an environmental consultant. Before taking part in the Institute of Politics’ panel discussion on climate change this Tuesday, Browner sat down with the Maroon and shared her insights on how climate legislation failed in Congress in 2010, what to expect from Obama’s second term, and why it’s so hard to get people serious about climate change. Chicago Maroon: What would you say is the main reason that the 2010 cap-and-trade bill, the last major attempt at climate change legislation, did not pass the Senate? Carol Browner: One of the primary reasons they never even got to a debate is that they ran out of time. They ran out of time because there was eight weeks that Max Baucus and [Chuck] Grassley spent trying to get an agreement on health care. Ted Kennedy died; I mean, a lot of things happened. Having said that, there were some pretty significant disagreements in the Senate, and we never really got the chance to see if we could bridge those disagreements. And they existed between Democrats and Republicans—we did have some Republican support, but they also existed among Democrats themselves. CM: President Obama talked in grand terms during his inaugural address about dealing with climate change. What do you expect him to do in his second term? CB: First of all, chicagomaroonDOTcom/2013/04/26/uncommon-interview-carol-browner/

Message.Title: Total Shareholder Returns: XOM vs CVX
Message.Msg: Total shareholder returns (i.e. stock appreciation plus dividends) for XOM are lagging 87% behind Cheveron's since Tillerson became Chairman and CEO. Apparently XOM's board does not think that this relative performance is a problem in setting Tillerson's compensation package. Go figure.

Message.Title: P/E of eight
Message.Msg: I must be nuts to own a blue chip highly dependable stock whose P/E is stuck at eight. A ten percent dividend increase does not make up for this pathetic investment. We need a 4% yield at the very LEAST! Oh, wait, I forgot management needs the money for their golf club memberships.
